s.text: It's hard to imagine that West could ever have written a conventional novel with any success.
It's hard to imagine that West could ever have written a conventional novel with any success.

It's hard to imagine that West could ever have written a conventional novel with any success.
It's hard to imagine that West could ever have written a conventional novel with any success.

He tried in The Day of the Locust (1939), with its more or less realistic story of Hollywood down and outs, but mostly he succeeded in placing a veneer of hard-boiled literary conventions over his manias about women and sex, which makes him seem just as crazy as in his other books, but less aware of it, therefore less entertaining.

He tried in The Day of the Locust (1939), with its more or less realistic story of Hollywood down and outs, but mostly he succeeded in placing a veneer of hard-boiled literary conventions over his manias about women and sex, which makes him seem just as crazy as in his other books, but less aware of it, therefore less entertaining.

He tried in The Day of the Locust (1939), with its more or less realistic story of Hollywood down and outs, but mostly he succeeded in placing a veneer of hard-boiled literary conventions over his manias about women and sex, which makes him seem just as crazy as in his other books, but less aware of it, therefore less entertaining.
He meets a little boy, who shows him his writings, and he meets his old writing teacher, Miss McGeeney, who shows him her writings.
He meets a little boy, who shows him his writings, and he meets his old writing teacher, Miss McGeeney, who shows him her writings.

For you feel, in The Dream Life , that West has filmed a jerky-camera record of his own dream life, and that each new, ridiculous scene represents a further unfolding of an altogether real and plausible personality.
But the key to understanding him lies in the first of his novels, The Dream Life of Balso Snell , which took three years to write, from 1926 to 1929, and ended up 49 pages long.
There's much to be said for the tone of comic-book violence: "He buried his triangular face like the blade of a hatchet in her neck."
An intelligent man finds it easy to laugh at himself, but his laughter is not sincere if it is thorough.
But A Cool Million is, in its modest way, the most perfect of his books.
